paper_title: Photocatalytic CO 2 Reduction of C/ZnO Nanofibers Enhanced by Ni-NiS Cocatalyst

catalyst.source: In the present paper, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared via the in situ photodeposition of compact Ni-NiS nanosheets onto C/ZnO electrospun nanofibers.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into valuable hydrocarbon fuel via solar energy is a promising strategy for carbon utilization.In the present paper, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared via the in situ photodeposition of compact Ni-NiS nanosheets onto C/ZnO electrospun nanofibers.The existence of metallic Ni and NiS was confirmed by Xray photoelectron spectroscopy.Photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL spectroscopy revealed that the cocatalyst Ni-NiS enhances the charge separation efficiency of C/ZnO nanofibers.The as-prepared Ni-NiS/C/ZnO showed enhanced CO 2 reduction activity with CO and CH 4 production rates 10 and 15 times greater than those of pristine C/ZnO under 350 W visible light illumination.The intermediates of CH 3 O -, HCHO, and HCOO -were detected by in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and confirmed that CO 2 reduction is a complex reaction with multiple steps.The 13 C isotopic tracer method proved that CH 4 and CO are obtained from the reduction of CO 2 rather than other carbon species in the environment.The amorphous carbon in C/ZnO could promote optical absorption, improve conductivity and reduce the interfacial charge transport resistance.Ni-NiS improved the electron-hole-pair separation of C/ZnO nanofibers.The observed enhancement in photocatalytic activity was largely attributed to higher light utilization and effective electron-hole separation.This work proves that Ni-NiS is a promising cocatalyst to ZnO for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.

catalyst.source: Ni-NiS/C/ZnO composite photocatalysts were prepared by in situ photochemical deposition.
catalyst.context: Ni-NiS/C/ZnO composite photocatalysts were prepared by in situ photochemical deposition.In detail, 100 mg of C/ZnO nanofibers was added to a mixture solution of 5 mL of Ni(CH 3 COO) 2 aqueous solution (0.05 mol L -1 ), 5 mL of thiourea aqueous solution (0.5 mol L -1 ), and 40 ml of a mixed solution of H 2 O and ethanol (volume ratio 1:1).Then, the resultant suspension was bubbled with high purity N 2 for 40 min to remove air.Irradiation was carried out for a given period (20-120 min) with a 350 W Xe arc lamp (UV-visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ) at room temperature (see Electronic Supplementary Information Fig. S1).Finally, the ash-black products were collected by suction filtration, washed repeatedly with H 2 O and alcohol, and dried in a 60 C vacuum oven for 24 h.The content of Ni-NiS in the samples was controlled by adjusting the photodeposition time.The asprepared Ni-NiS/C/ZnO nanomaterials were designated C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 to indicate deposition times of 20, 60, and 120 min, respectively.C-Z and NNS represent pristine C/ZnO nanofibers and Ni-NiS respectively.The precise contents of each element in C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Table 1).Besides, the Ni/NiS mass ratio for samples C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60 and C-ZNNS120 were presented in Electronic Supplementary Information Table S1. The actual elemental contents of C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 were determined through ICP-AES.X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D/Max-RB Xray diffractometer (see Electronic Supplementary Information, Fig. S2).Sample morphologies were observed on a JSM 7500F field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry were conducted on a Titan G2 60-300 electron microscope.N 2 /CO 2 adsorptiondesorption data were recorded on a Micromeritics ASAP 3020 N 2 adsorption apparatus (USA) at 423.15 K. Pore size distributions were determined by using desorption data via the Barret-Joyner-Halenda method.The ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) diffuse reflectance spectra of samples were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with Al K X-ray radiation.In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Nicolet iS50, TMO, USA) was used to monitor the photocatalytic CO 2 reaction process online. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and Mott-Schottky (M-S) measurements were measured by using an electrochemical analyzer (CHI660C Instruments) in a standard three-electrode system in which a Pt wire and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) were set as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively.EIS measurements were carried out by applying a bias of 10 mV and recording over the frequency range of 0.01-10 5 Hz.All applied potentials were converted to that of a normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), NHE Ag/AgCl .0.197 V Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was carried out in a 200 mL home-made Pyrex reactor according to our previously reported method.A 350 W simulated solar Xe arc lamp (Zhenjian Silver Jewelry Chemical, China) was used as the light source in photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 (visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ).Blank experiments were carried out in the absence of CO The instrument was equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID).N 2 was used as carrier gas during the test.The photocatalytic products were taken from the photocatalytic reactor by a 100 uL sampler and then injected into the instrument for detection.The morphologies of the samples were explored by using FESEM and TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 1.Pristine C-Z had smooth nanofibers with an average diameter of 400 nm (Fig. 1a andinset).Numerous Ni-NiS nanosheets grew out of the C-Z nanofibers upon photodeposition (Fig. 1b andinset).The optical properties of the materials were studied to determine their optical absorption properties, 48 and the results are shown in Fig. 2. Compared with commercial ZnO, C-Z could absorb UV and some near-infrared light due to its carbon content. 49The absorption of C-ZNNS60 was greatly improved compared with that of pristine C-Z due to the dark color and narrow band gap of Ni-NiS. 50Among the samples studied, NNS possessed the best absorption properties, which is mainly due to its black coloration and photothermal effects.Moreover, the higher the cocatalyst loading, the better the absorbance observed (see Electronic Supplementary Information, Fig. S3).These results indicate that adding carbon and loading with the cocatalyst favor absorption and could effectively improve the photocatalytic activity of the photocatalysts. 51he surface area (S BET ), pore volume (V p ) and average pore size (d p ) of the resultant samples were measured by N 2 sorption technique.The N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of C-Z, NNS, C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60 and C-ZNNS120 were presented in Fig. 3a.The isotherms of five samples can be considered to be type IV isotherm.In addition, we can observe H3 type hysteresis rings from their characteristics, which generally means that there are a lot of lamellar materials forming slit holes.The pore size distributions of different samples are illustrated in the inset of Fig. 3a.Compared with C-Z, the composites possessed more mesopores around 3 nm, which caused by the tiny slits accumulated by Ni-NiS nanosheets.

catalyst.source: In this work, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared by photodepositing Ni-NiS nanosheets onto electrospun C/ZnO nanofibers.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was carried out in a 200 mL home-made Pyrex reactor according to our previously reported method.A 350 W simulated solar Xe arc lamp (Zhenjian Silver Jewelry Chemical, China) was used as the light source in photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 (visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ).Blank experiments were carried out in the absence of CO 2 or light irradiation to confirm that CO 2 Fig. 1.FESEM images of (a) C-Z and (b) C-ZNNS60.Insets: Corresponding enlarged images.(c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of C-ZNNS60.(e) EDX elemental mapping of C-ZNNS60. Fig. 1c reveals the existence of Ni-NiS nanosheets and confirms that Ni-NiS is tightly attached to the C-Z surface.The highresolution TEM (HRTEM) image in Fig. 1d shows lattice spacings of 0.106 and 0.16 nm, which respectively correspond to hexagonal ZnO (110) and rhombohedral NiS (211) facets.These results agree with the XRD results and demonstrate that Ni-NiS is indeed uniformly deposited on the C-Z nanofibers.The EDX elemental mapping of C-ZNNS60 (Fig. 1e) proves that the sample contains Zn, O, Ni, S, and C elements, thus confirming the existence of C/ZnO and Ni-NiS. Fig. 2. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra of commercial ZnO, C-Z, C-ZNNS60, and NNS. Fig. 3. (a) XPS survey spectra of C-Z and C-ZNNS60.high-resolution XPS spectra of (b) Zn 2p, (c) O 1s of C-Z and C-ZNNS60, (c) Ni 2p and (d) S 2p of NNS and C-ZNNS60. View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C9NR10451H In this work, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared by photodepositing Ni-NiS nanosheets onto electrospun C/ZnO nanofibers.We found that Ni-NiS can remarkably enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of C/ZnO nanofibers when applied as a cocatalyst.Ni-NiS/C/ZnO favored the adsorption of CO 2 due to chemical adsorption between the cocatalyst and CO 2 molecules.Furthermore, part of the Ni 2 is reduced by e CB-and the cocatalyst Ni-NiS is formed during sample preparation; this cocatalyst serves as an electron sink and suppresses the rapid recombination of e CB-and h VB during the photocatalytic process.Hence, the functions of Ni-NiS are confirmed to increase the adsorption of CO 2 on the cocatalyst Ni-NiS surface and promote e CB-migration from C/ZnO nanofibers to the Ni-NiS nanosheets to CO 2 molecules.Amorphous carbon functions as an electron storage and electron enrichment center due to its good electrical conductivity.Besides, it can effectively remedy the poor light utilization of ZnO by improving its absorbance and broadening its wavelength range.Moreover, the exist of amorphous carbon could reduce the interfacial charge transport resistance and promote the migration ability of photogenerated electrons.Our work provides new insights into approaches to enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of ZnO by addition of carbon and loading with the transition metal cocatalyst Ni-NiS. The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and Mott-Schottky (M-S) measurements were measured by using an electrochemical analyzer (CHI660C Instruments) in a standard three-electrode system in which a Pt wire and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) were set as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively.EIS measurements were carried out by applying a bias of 10 mV and recording over the frequency range of 0.01-10 5 Hz.All applied potentials were converted to that of a normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), NHE Ag/AgCl .0.197 V Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was carried out in a 200 mL home-made Pyrex reactor according to our previously reported method.A 350 W simulated solar Xe arc lamp (Zhenjian Silver Jewelry Chemical, China) was used as the light source in photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 (visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ).Blank experiments were carried out in the absence of CO The instrument was equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID).N 2 was used as carrier gas during the test.The photocatalytic products were taken from the photocatalytic reactor by a 100 uL sampler and then injected into the instrument for detection.The morphologies of the samples were explored by using FESEM and TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 1.Pristine C-Z had smooth nanofibers with an average diameter of 400 nm (Fig. 1a andinset).Numerous Ni-NiS nanosheets grew out of the C-Z nanofibers upon photodeposition (Fig. 1b andinset).The optical properties of the materials were studied to determine their optical absorption properties, 48 and the results are shown in Fig. 2. Compared with commercial ZnO, C-Z could absorb UV and some near-infrared light due to its carbon content. 49The absorption of C-ZNNS60 was greatly improved compared with that of pristine C-Z due to the dark color and narrow band gap of Ni-NiS. 50Among the samples studied, NNS possessed the best absorption properties, which is mainly due to its black coloration and photothermal effects.Moreover, the higher the cocatalyst loading, the better the absorbance observed (see Electronic Supplementary Information, Fig. S3).These results indicate that adding carbon and loading with the cocatalyst favor absorption and could effectively improve the photocatalytic activity of the photocatalysts. 51he surface area (S BET ), pore volume (V p ) and average pore size (d p ) of the resultant samples were measured by N 2 sorption technique.The N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of C-Z, NNS, C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60 and C-ZNNS120 were presented in Fig. 3a.The isotherms of five samples can be considered to be type IV isotherm.In addition, we can observe H3 type hysteresis rings from their characteristics, which generally means that there are a lot of lamellar materials forming slit holes.The pore size distributions of different samples are illustrated in the inset of Fig. 3a.Compared with C-Z, the composites possessed more mesopores around 3 nm, which caused by the tiny slits accumulated by Ni-NiS nanosheets.

View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C9NR10451H In this work, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared by photodepositing Ni-NiS nanosheets onto electrospun C/ZnO nanofibers.We found that Ni-NiS can remarkably enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of C/ZnO nanofibers when applied as a cocatalyst.Ni-NiS/C/ZnO favored the adsorption of CO 2 due to chemical adsorption between the cocatalyst and CO 2 molecules.Furthermore, part of the Ni 2 is reduced by e CB-and the cocatalyst Ni-NiS is formed during sample preparation; this cocatalyst serves as an electron sink and suppresses the rapid recombination of e CB-and h VB during the photocatalytic process.Hence, the functions of Ni-NiS are confirmed to increase the adsorption of CO 2 on the cocatalyst Ni-NiS surface and promote e CB-migration from C/ZnO nanofibers to the Ni-NiS nanosheets to CO 2 molecules.Amorphous carbon functions as an electron storage and electron enrichment center due to its good electrical conductivity.Besides, it can effectively remedy the poor light utilization of ZnO by improving its absorbance and broadening its wavelength range.Moreover, the exist of amorphous carbon could reduce the interfacial charge transport resistance and promote the migration ability of photogenerated electrons.Our work provides new insights into approaches to enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of ZnO by addition of carbon and loading with the transition metal cocatalyst Ni-NiS. The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

lamp.source: Irradiation was carried out for a given period (20-120 min) with a 350 W Xe arc lamp (UV-visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ) at room temperature (see Electronic Supplementary Information Fig. S1).
lamp.context: Ni-NiS/C/ZnO composite photocatalysts were prepared by in situ photochemical deposition.In detail, 100 mg of C/ZnO nanofibers was added to a mixture solution of 5 mL of Ni(CH 3 COO) 2 aqueous solution (0.05 mol L -1 ), 5 mL of thiourea aqueous solution (0.5 mol L -1 ), and 40 ml of a mixed solution of H 2 O and ethanol (volume ratio 1:1).Then, the resultant suspension was bubbled with high purity N 2 for 40 min to remove air.Irradiation was carried out for a given period (20-120 min) with a 350 W Xe arc lamp (UV-visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ) at room temperature (see Electronic Supplementary Information Fig. S1).Finally, the ash-black products were collected by suction filtration, washed repeatedly with H 2 O and alcohol, and dried in a 60 C vacuum oven for 24 h.The content of Ni-NiS in the samples was controlled by adjusting the photodeposition time.The asprepared Ni-NiS/C/ZnO nanomaterials were designated C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 to indicate deposition times of 20, 60, and 120 min, respectively.C-Z and NNS represent pristine C/ZnO nanofibers and Ni-NiS respectively.The precise contents of each element in C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Table 1).Besides, the Ni/NiS mass ratio for samples C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60 and C-ZNNS120 were presented in Electronic Supplementary Information Table S1. View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C9NR10451H In this work, a hierarchical Ni-NiS/C/ZnO photocatalyst was prepared by photodepositing Ni-NiS nanosheets onto electrospun C/ZnO nanofibers.We found that Ni-NiS can remarkably enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of C/ZnO nanofibers when applied as a cocatalyst.Ni-NiS/C/ZnO favored the adsorption of CO 2 due to chemical adsorption between the cocatalyst and CO 2 molecules.Furthermore, part of the Ni 2 is reduced by e CB-and the cocatalyst Ni-NiS is formed during sample preparation; this cocatalyst serves as an electron sink and suppresses the rapid recombination of e CB-and h VB during the photocatalytic process.Hence, the functions of Ni-NiS are confirmed to increase the adsorption of CO 2 on the cocatalyst Ni-NiS surface and promote e CB-migration from C/ZnO nanofibers to the Ni-NiS nanosheets to CO 2 molecules.Amorphous carbon functions as an electron storage and electron enrichment center due to its good electrical conductivity.Besides, it can effectively remedy the poor light utilization of ZnO by improving its absorbance and broadening its wavelength range.Moreover, the exist of amorphous carbon could reduce the interfacial charge transport resistance and promote the migration ability of photogenerated electrons.Our work provides new insights into approaches to enhance the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of ZnO by addition of carbon and loading with the transition metal cocatalyst Ni-NiS. operation mode.source: The photocatalytic products were taken from the photocatalytic reactor by a 100 uL sampler and then injected into the instrument for detection.
operation mode.context: Ni-NiS/C/ZnO composite photocatalysts were prepared by in situ photochemical deposition.In detail, 100 mg of C/ZnO nanofibers was added to a mixture solution of 5 mL of Ni(CH 3 COO) 2 aqueous solution (0.05 mol L -1 ), 5 mL of thiourea aqueous solution (0.5 mol L -1 ), and 40 ml of a mixed solution of H 2 O and ethanol (volume ratio 1:1).Then, the resultant suspension was bubbled with high purity N 2 for 40 min to remove air.Irradiation was carried out for a given period (20-120 min) with a 350 W Xe arc lamp (UV-visible light, average light intensity10117 W/cm 2 ) at room temperature (see Electronic Supplementary Information Fig. S1).Finally, the ash-black products were collected by suction filtration, washed repeatedly with H 2 O and alcohol, and dried in a 60 C vacuum oven for 24 h.The content of Ni-NiS in the samples was controlled by adjusting the photodeposition time.The asprepared Ni-NiS/C/ZnO nanomaterials were designated C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 to indicate deposition times of 20, 60, and 120 min, respectively.C-Z and NNS represent pristine C/ZnO nanofibers and Ni-NiS respectively.The precise contents of each element in C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Table 1).Besides, the Ni/NiS mass ratio for samples C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60 and C-ZNNS120 were presented in Electronic Supplementary Information Table S1. The actual elemental contents of C-ZNNS20, C-ZNNS60, and C-ZNNS120 were determined through ICP-AES.X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D/Max-RB Xray diffractometer (see Electronic Supplementary Information, Fig. S2).Sample morphologies were observed on a JSM 7500F field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry were conducted on a Titan G2 60-300 electron microscope.N 2 /CO 2 adsorptiondesorption data were recorded on a Micromeritics ASAP 3020 N 2 adsorption apparatus (USA) at 423.15 K.
